[davido], [localtime://2011-08-17 13:18:10]
I just wanted to provide an explanation for an edit of [id://920659].

Background: This was the OP's seventh post, and most of the previous ones had formatting problems. He has been asked several times via /msg as well as by followups to his nodes to read [id://17558] and format accordingly.

Now: When [id://920659] was posted I saw that it was gathering downvotes and "please read this" replies. I /msg'ed the OP to let him know that he should read [id://17558] and edit his post accordingly. Seven hours later it hadn't been done. Someone considered the node for editing, and it gathered a vote of 0/11/1 (11 for edit). I edited the node so that its formatting would match the original raw input from the OP, and sent him a message letting him know what was done, why, and where to learn how to format properly in the first place.

I left a small blurb at the bottom of his node identifying that the node had been edited. I know we have sort of gotten away from doing that in general, but this time I did it for two reasons: First, because then he would see someone worked on it for him, and second, so that all the "I can't read this node" replies would have a contextual reference point.

I look back over old nodes here in the Monastery. "Back in the day" it seems like there were fewer "Please read xxxx, please read yyy" followups. I am afraid we (the Monks in general) have gotten in the habit of following up in public with what probably ought to be done in private.

Just a thought.

[ysth], [localtime://2007-05-14 20:25:34]
I see three topics here; the trollishness, meditationness, and off-topicness of the post in question:

I think taking extra action like moving to offtopic in response to trollishness is like waving a red flag in front of a bull. I'd really rather not see trolls go there.

I really don't want to get into the business of judging whether something that claims to be a meditation is really a meditation. I don't see anything productive coming of that. If it were clearly not an attempt at a meditation, and didn't fit under any other category, it might be a candidate for offtopic. But this is far from such a case. (AFAIK there isn't consensus about what to use offtopic for, but my inclination is to use it for things that are offtopic and are also not question/meditation/etc. sparingly, particularly when such a node gets moved multiple times and is creating a furor over what to do with it.)

I really don't want to get into the business of judging whether something that claims to be about perl is really about perl. This particular node has me pretty much in the dark as to its actual point; this especially is a flag to me to just leave it alone.

[tye], [localtime://2007-05-14 19:37:30]

As for "discouraging trolling" the immediate reaction of the author in this case was to offer to repost it. The best thing to do with trolls is to ignore them, not give them special status, something to shoot for or to rail against (or, as some would surely claim, to pretend to rail against).

I suspect that the consensus is that the node was not off topic and so it was inappropriate to designate as completely off-topic by putting it into the non-section. But others need to speak up either way.

I haven't seen the author complaining about the characterizations made about his node. He certainly did complain about it being labeled as "off topic", which of course he would if he isn't going to stop pretending.

My response to the troll nodes is mostly to downvote replies, especially replies that go on-and-on about this troll and that troll. Sometimes I notice someone who appears to have a problem with being able to ignore trolling and I /msg them.

[tye], [localtime://2007-01-07 01:38:44]
Such people cannot come back under the same name. I make sure of that, actually. And coming back under a different name gives them no power to re-wipe the nodes that were reverted and so makes no difference on this point. I meant "user" as in the authorization unit, not as in the person behind it.

I guess I have seen node contents restored and didn't see a scuffle break out. In some cases, anyway, it may have been a wake-up call and worked out fine (in most cases it appears to have not obviously worked out badly). But I still am uncomfortable with it conceptually and am usually uncomfortable with it in practice and so usually won't execute such requests. I'm uncomfortable even with just some of the implications of the request being made.

In one case, there was a user having clear difficulty and they expressed difficulty with restoring the content and so janitorial assistance, though not explicitly and clearly requested, seemed appropriate.

So, I think such considerations are tollerable as a way to show the author how many people think the content should be restored. But I'd rather the janitorial role be to ask the user to do the restoration themselves, pointing them to documentation about how to better deal with regret, or at least getting permission before restoring.

Unfortunately, I don't see a stellar method for a janitor to take up such tasks, preventing of piling-on of cajoling from janitors. I guess a note in the wiki will do.
